nodes.bodyText: Is there any reason that the Location variable's name is plural while the array variable above (line 2) is singular?
Updated

It's a bit odd that a location object has a plural name while location list's name is singular, can you rename the variables in this file in this way:

expectedLocation for single objects
expectedLocationList for arrays
Updated

nodes.bodyText:
Can you make this one line?
Or you can write:
import * as expectedResults from 'src/app/entity/mockLocationData';
and use those expected consts by expectedResults.expectedLocation etc. in this file.
Updated
Is this "as ApiResponse" redundant?
Yes. As per the previous comments form nikk we have changed according to that "as ApiResponse".
Got that, in that way, do you mind just keeping "as ApiResponse" and removing the ApiResponse type declaration in line 108?

I just updated as you suggested.

Could you please re confirm that you can able to see the changes.
Yes, confirmed.
nit: toHaveBeenCalledTimes
Updated
This is the method you just spied on, don't call spies in tests. Did you mean to spy on the service?
I have updated the test case title.
You updated the title, but this is still the same, you are still immediately calling the method you spied on. The spy needs to be on the service.
Test case is updated according to the component changes
nit: use String(...) or ...toString() consistently
Sure.
nit: You don't need include .model in these file names. add-site-response.ts would be preferred.
Updated.
This interface extends ApiResponse, but you are creating it here. There should be a separate AddSiteRequest and AddSiteResponse.
This can use an async pipe.

nodes.bodyText: unsubscribe here
As we are subscribing to this.$study using the async pipe in the component template. async pipe will unsubscribe automatically on destroy

If you use "==" operands, it doesn't check the type but instead convert everything to number and compare, so I think '' == 0, you may need only two comparison here: locationId == 0 || locationiD == null.
